stories.title: Try out the easy and friendly Operating System(s)

stories.text: The freebie Beats headphones that Apple threw in with my daughter's MacBookAir when she went to college are on the fritz. Looking for a replacement so I can jam and tune out coworker noise for long hours of coding. Something wireless, ANC, and works well with the 16" MBP (and affordable).
stories.title: Over ear wireless headphone recommendations for many hours of coding?
Clubhouse is now out of beta

stories.text:
Hey HN!

The metaverse is not one app. It's a network of thousands of virtual worlds people visit daily to play games, work, and collaborate. To unlock the full potential of the metaverse, those worlds need to be connected. Today we're making a big step towards making that happen.

Ready Player Me is an avatar platform used by 260+ companies, including VRChat, Somnium Space, Mozilla Hubs, and others. Today, we are launching our biggest update ever, taking us closer to our vision – create a platform that allows you to keep a consistent identity in virtual worlds and the Metaverse.

The Ready Player Me Hub allows you to create one or multiple avatars and use it in all supported applications in a few clicks. We shared more details on our blog.

We are very excited about this big step towards making the Metaverse dream real.

The hub: https://readyplayer.me/

Coverage in our blog: https://blog.readyplayer.me/3d-avatars-from-photo-metaverse-hub/
stories.title: Ready Player Me Hub – cross-game avatar platform for the Metaverse

NSO group say enough is enough

stories.text:
Yet again another crypto scam video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TXOGMwRREKw

and another one

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SRVwBycWM4Y

you can see it is hacked because it has Russian text and all the content deleted

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCc4RCianmeeKwJwKT9sJtNg/community

here is the original not-scam video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TowDxSHSClw

These scammers copy the content of an existing event, such as the Bezos Blue Origin launch, and then after having the video play for the first 30-50 minutes, will switch to a screen promoting a giveaway url. It's a pretty ingenious workaround.

This is way more lucrative than any other scam in the world. A single video can make $300k , or about the same as a large ransomware payout, but without having to worry about the Secret Service, the FBI, or having tainted crypto.

YouTube is trying to stop these videos by algorithmically detecting certain characters and other markers indicative of the scam, although the huge profitability of this scam ensures scammers will keep finding ways to innovate and stay a few steps ahead of YouTube.

It seems these scammers have unlimited hacked YouTube channels at their disposal, especially high quality channels with a lot of followers and view history. You would think YouTube would be able to implement better ways to prevent channels from being hacked and or have systems to lock-out accounts that have indications of being hacked.
stories.title: Arc Invest Livestream Crypto Scam on YouTube
